insights.title: Financial Committee Leaders Show High Cross-Correlation
insights.summary: Key financial oversight committee leaders demonstrate significant cross-correlation between PAC receipts and stock trading activity. French Hill leads with $218,000 in financial PAC contributions and $450,000 in stock trades while chairing the Financial Services Committee.
insights.detailed_summary:
Analysis reveals **strong cross-correlation patterns** among members holding key financial oversight positions. [[official:french_hill|French Hill]] (R-AR), who chairs the [[committee:house-financial-services|House Financial Services Committee]], received the highest financial sector PAC contributions at **$218,000** while also conducting up to **$450,000** in stock trades, primarily in [[industry:banking|banking and depository]] sectors.

[[official:dave_mccormick|Dave McCormick]] (R-PA) presents the most significant cross-correlation case, serving as Vice Chair of the [[committee:senate-banking|Senate Banking Committee]] while receiving **$115,000** in financial PAC contributions and conducting **$5,000,000** in stock trades, exclusively in [[industry:investment|investment and securities]].

Additional cross-correlation patterns emerge among [[committee:house-financial-services|Financial Services Committee]] members including [[official:ritchie_torres|Ritchie Torres]] (D-NY) with **$126,000** PAC/$165,000 trades, [[official:greg_landsman|Greg Landsman]] (D-OH) with **$95,000** PAC/$145,000 trades, and [[official:josh_gottheimer|Josh Gottheimer]] (D-NJ) with **$54,000** PAC/$770,000 trades.

These patterns indicate **concentrated financial activity** among officials with direct regulatory oversight responsibilities, with total cross-correlated activity exceeding **$7.5 million** in combined PAC contributions and stock trading volumes.
insights.evidence: FEC PAC contribution filings and STOCK Act disclosure reports

sources.title: House Financial Services Committee Member PAC Reports

insights.title: Republican Financial PAC Advantage Nearly 2:1
insights.summary: Republicans received $1,016,500 in financial sector PAC contributions compared to $527,500 for Democrats. This represents a significant 1.93:1 funding advantage favoring Republican members.
insights.detailed_summary:
Financial sector Political Action Committees demonstrate **clear partisan preference** in contribution patterns, with Republicans receiving nearly **twice the funding** of their Democratic counterparts. The aggregate data shows Republicans collected **$1,016,500** in financial PAC contributions versus **$527,500** for Democrats, representing a **1.93:1 advantage**.

The top Republican recipients dominate the highest contribution tiers, with [[official:french_hill|French Hill]] leading at **$218,000**, followed by [[official:dave_mccormick|Dave McCormick]] at **$115,000**, and [[official:lisa_mcclain|Lisa McClain]] at **$100,000**. Republican members occupy **7 of the top 10** PAC recipient positions.

Democratic recipients show more modest contribution levels, with [[official:ritchie_torres|Ritchie Torres]] leading Democratic recipients at **$126,000**, followed by [[official:greg_landsman|Greg Landsman]] at **$95,000** and [[official:jake_auchincloss|Jake Auchincloss]] at **$85,500**. The concentration suggests **strategic industry preference** for Republican policy positions on financial regulation.

This partisan distribution pattern affects **304 tracked officials** and indicates systematic industry preference that could influence regulatory oversight and legislative priorities in financial services committees.
insights.evidence: FEC Political Action Committee contribution reports

insights.title: Extreme Trading Concentration Among Few Members
insights.summary: Jefferson Shreve conducted $52.55 million in financial sector trades, representing over 50% of total tracked trading volume. The top 5 traders account for approximately $60 million in combined activity.
insights.detailed_summary:
Congressional financial sector stock trading shows **extreme concentration** among a small number of members, with [[official:jefferson_shreve|Jefferson Shreve]] (R-IN) conducting **$52.55 million** in trades (**$50.85M buys, $1.7M sells**) primarily in [[industry:investment|investment and securities]] and [[industry:banking|banking sectors]]. This single member's activity represents over **half of all tracked financial sector trading volume**.

The concentration pattern continues with [[official:dave_mccormick|Dave McCormick]] (R-PA) at **$5 million** (all sells in [[industry:investment|investment and securities]]), [[official:ro_khanna|Ro Khanna]] (D-CA) at **$2.4 million** (**$1.875M buys, $530K sells**), and [[official:julie_johnson|Julie Johnson]] (D-TX) at **$975,000** (**$285K buys, $690K sells**). These **top 4 traders** account for approximately **$61 million** in combined trading activity.

The remaining tracked members show significantly lower trading volumes, with most conducting transactions under **$1 million**. Notable mid-tier traders include [[official:michael_mccaul|Michael McCaul]] (R-TX) at **$970,000**, [[official:josh_gottheimer|Josh Gottheimer]] (D-NJ) at **$770,000**, and [[official:lisa_mcclain|Lisa McClain]] (R-MI) at **$735,000**.

This **extreme concentration pattern** raises transparency concerns, as a small number of members control the vast majority of congressional financial sector trading activity, with [[official:jefferson_shreve|Shreve's]] activity alone exceeding the combined trades of dozens of other members.
insights.evidence: STOCK Act periodic transaction reports and financial disclosure filings

officials.name: Jefferson Shreve
officials.detail: $50.85M buys, $1.7M sells - over 50% of total volume

insights.title: Emerging Crypto and Fintech Trading Patterns
insights.summary: Multiple members show concentrated trading in digital assets and financial technology sectors. Jonathan Jackson leads crypto trading with $355,000 in buys, while fintech trading spans both parties.
insights.detailed_summary:
Congressional trading data reveals **emerging concentration** in newer financial sectors, particularly [[industry:crypto|digital assets and cryptocurrency]] and [[industry:fintech|financial technology]]. [[official:jonathan_jackson|Jonathan Jackson]] (D-IL) leads cryptocurrency trading with **$355,000 in buys and $130,000 in sells**, making [[industry:crypto|digital assets]] his primary trading focus alongside [[industry:fintech|financial technology]].

[[industry:fintech|Financial technology]] trading shows **bipartisan activity** with significant volumes from [[official:michael_mccaul|Michael McCaul]] (R-TX) conducting **$970,000** in fintech and consumer lending trades, [[official:josh_gottheimer|Josh Gottheimer]] (D-NJ) with **$770,000** in fintech and consumer lending, and [[official:gilbert_cisneros|Gilbert Cisneros]] (D-CA) with **$575,000** split between fintech and crypto sectors.

[[official:tony_wied|Tony Wied]] (R-WI) demonstrates **cross-sector concentration** with **$700,000** in trades spanning [[industry:investment|investment securities]] and [[industry:crypto|digital assets]], while [[official:marjorie_greene|Marjorie Greene]] (R-GA) shows **$525,000** in buys focused on [[industry:fintech|financial technology]] and [[industry:investment|investment securities]] with no recorded sells.

This pattern suggests **evolving congressional interest** in emerging financial sectors, with total crypto-related trading exceeding **$1.5 million** and fintech trading surpassing **$3 million** across multiple members from both parties, indicating potential regulatory attention to these rapidly growing sectors.
insights.evidence: STOCK Act filings showing sector-specific trading classifications

industries.name: Financial Technology
industries.detail: Bipartisan trading interest across multiple members
